ï»¿Execution Version Dated October 9, 2014 COLLAB)RATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global Inirastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is entered into on October 9, 2014 between: (1) ALDWYCH HOLDINGS LIMITED, herein represented by its Managing Director, headquaril e at 30 King Street, London, EC2\' 8EH, United Kingdom ("Aldwych"); and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DIEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPIV E I\ ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, US!\, ie INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvar E Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("MiGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC :10 33, USA (the "World Bank Grou )") (each a "Party" and together, the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad international recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Inter 12 t, nal Organizations (1Os), the G77 and the private sector represented by the B20 that investin in the infrastructure of Emerging Markets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to q: ind access to basic services anc raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic - nlth targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on . :i ing sources of infrastructure fina ice-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and cooi:J n, ted effort is needed to mobilize p ivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robust pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects an t is understood to be the greates barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investm :nt (D) Governments, development f nance institutions, donors, and private investors share an in 3e t in developing the market for pr vate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand s d , in the numbers of structurally scund and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual emir ;1: ice of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range ol Ir ate investors that actively partic'pate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals will IIe )efit from collective action betwe n this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowl:1 ll( to find solutions to complex ifrastructure financing challenges that no single institutio ' ( 'uld achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, the Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructure FE ility Partnership Program ("GIF") The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at levera i i,: the efforts of the wide range of i istitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastruct.ii e vith the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project pre a' a on, structuring, and risk mitigati )n for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, I e GIF aims to complement existinq and proposed services and initiatives currently supportec :i the Parties and other prospective GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prep, r: /ell- structured, infrastructure prcjects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for acces iii; the expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from pro ;IE tive private sector financiers into Droject structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater I :!e age of official resources in the fe ce of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular 1:)- 1rge and complex projects with th a potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now interested in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure I- ility Partnership Program, togeth.r with other partners. 2
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have come to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure FacilitI Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended t) be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set oi tr Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Fot ndational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collat c ri ion, they are of an indicative nature and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties and v I other potential partners until tie GIF is formally established. The final version of these obje :. IN !s and principles will be agreed ipon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend to work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to fu ther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing t I IF, with a view to formally establi 3hing the program by December 2014. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the foreg )ing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue t' collaborate in developing the SIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of :ollaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the rfles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each categol J( b. Governance arrangements of the GIF; c. Operational policies a:pplicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activities and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to proj( ,t selection criteria and coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, incluc r g sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through t 13 L e of knowledge platforr is for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finali2 ing the design of the GIF, the multilateral development banI s I ted in Annex 2 will be invited 1b participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF d :ini; I is finalized, additional collaboiative efforts are required to develop the operational details 10 the GIF, at all times complem.nting existing efforts and facilities and building upon the ,1 red knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the E v I of coordination between the Pirties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration Ai rangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitmeni t y he Parties to enter into or provide support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisions of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their commc 1 understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose a- gal obligations or liabilities on an j Party. 3.2 This Collaboration Ai rangement is valid and effective for a period of one year fron h: date thereof, unless superse led at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect ti at this document and information with respect to the collaboi :31:i' activities contemplated herei i will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' respective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult wil ' e. ch 3
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manner ind form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's support regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arrang ement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciatic'c other modification of any of the privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of thE Parties under their constituen documents, international conventions and any applicable law . In witness whereof, each of the Part es has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be execute 1 ir two (2) counterparts of equal content ind form by a duly authorized representative of each Party a! :1 he date first set forth above. 4
ï»¿Execution Version ALDWYCH HOLDINGS LIMITED By: HELEN TARNOY, MANAGING DIRECTOR 5
ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIOI I 41 D DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: Y G KIM, PRESIDENT 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 1 Preliffinary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the IF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure pl : e ts in emerging markets and developing economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparatilI , provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercial zn institutional investor engagerr ent in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex publi-private partnerships and projects with potential for commer :Ji viability which require project Dreparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastru :t.j financing solutions that no single institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF z ims to create a global platform to provide financial and coorc ral on resources in collaboration wit i the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of th * le range of donor and development finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMD infrastructure, with the input and ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engagemer tc uld stretch from upstream support on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to downstream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risk mitigation/credit enhancement. 1.3 Over the longer term, by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structure:1 infrastructure projects, the GI - can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset cla!s attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking long tir i assets in faster growing econ mies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment opp )rtunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profile : 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to operate according to the following core principles, to be finalizE d L on agreement among GIF partn rs: (i) Leveraging the )rivate sector-specializing in project financing modalities tt I ill draw together co nparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing public goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly thosE infrastructure prciects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sustaiinability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to t 3f practice standar s for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing tE c. cal and financial resources of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mu :ia ral development institutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in ar innovative and flexible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greatr leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that are beyond the resources of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in t'if development and implementation of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF pi r r rs are expected to fall into one or more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partners-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF wil la considered Fundi ig Partners. (ii) Technical Partners-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice ind support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-funde: activities and/or provision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity suppc 1 instruments. (iii) Advisory Partners-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/c r institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, soveeign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as wE II a other multilateral or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure pro ects, to be invited into discussions related to project prepara cI optimal approach as to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, with a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional inves:ment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Council is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programmin I. management and use of fund 3, and development of operational policies and procedures; 2 n :1 hold the GIF Management Ur it (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, witt advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The compo! illc of the Governing Council will be agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is prop( sa to comprise representatives of F unding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Council comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing DirE c I( and Chief Financial Officer of the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facili :E coordination of GIF activities 3nd support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve : sounding board, providing gu dance and support for GIF Management, and in particular wi 1- view to ensuring suitability of projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be admi iistered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicate( e, m established for this purpose (:he GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will fL 1:11 >n as a coordinating body as prjects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mo% . toward technical support and financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead in( i,i Jal projects. 4.2 GIF activity implementation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partne institutions, coordinated by tie GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governme vs according to specific project requirements and the project origination processes. Compos ti:i of the implementation teams may vary according to the need of individual projects and gove nr1T !nts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection criteria and processes could be developed to reflect the follo%i i principles: (i) Development Impact-projects that support the development goals of the Gl partner institutio is; (ii) Alignment-pro ects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities a,i strategies; (iii) Complexity-pr)jects that require multiple parties to come together to provid:. structuring, arrar ging and financial support, and/or projects which require a b| :?tI of financial instrum ants; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impact -projects that have significant potential to achieve financial i 1l lity, leverage public funds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- ; aI as through Public -Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's ser /ice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastrL cture investments that have global public good characteristic : ; ich as climate friendly-projects that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provision cf infrastructure services; and tride enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconnet t / and trade. 5.2 The scope of suppo t provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with I'v !w to complementing the resources and support already available from partner entities and ot lor funding mechanisms. During he GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following ac -ii 3s, corresponding to major project development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; project definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scr!.r g; and legal, regulatory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparation and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and PFIP structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, and design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arranging and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financi 1 packages from a range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies-iicluding in particular the management of environmental and i;nc 31 impacts and risks, and transparency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastr it ti e projects in supporting sustainable, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements cr external implementing entitie: under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an arproach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards an( it er standards and policies, and c evelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for GI:: Technical Partners who are Expected to function as implementing entities for GIF activities 9
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 2 Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs) and their Respective Project Preparation Resources and Initiatives During the process of finalizing the design of the GIF, the following MDBs will be invited to particil i t' as initial Technical Partners. The opera ional details for the GIF will at all times complement the i ng efforts and facilities of these MDBE, which include but are not limited to the infrastructure p, 3ct preparation resources and initiatives listed below: a. African Developmerit Bank (AfDB) - NEPAD Infrastructure Project Preparation = lity (NEPAD-IPPF) as woll as the project development business segment of Africa i) nd various support effort; for Africa-focused PPFs; b. Asian Development Bank (ADB) - Office of Public-Private Partnership and its pr:q Ied Asia Pacific Project Preparation Facility ('AP3F') as well as several dedicated r E ti: rial PPFs; c. European Bank foi Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) - Legal Tr; ir s ion Programme, and the )roposed EBRD Infrastructure Project Preparation Facility ('IPI I ); d. European Investment Bank (EIB) - European PPP Expertise Centre (EPEC); e. Inter-American Devulopment Bank (IADB) - 'InfraFund' project preparation facili y f. Islamic Developmer t Bank (IsDB) - Arab Financing Facility for Infrastructure TE ci cal Assistance Facility (AFFI TAF), co-managed with the International Finance Cor cri ion (IFC); and g. World Bank Group (WBG) comprising the International Bank for Reconstruct :i ind Development (IBRD) the International Development Association (IDA), the Inters til nal Finance Corporation IFC), and the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MI 3 10
